{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3131752,"name":"rafi","username":"rafi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rafi/{size}/9207_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-22T05:14:21.064Z","cooked":"

I’ve spent the last week or so experimenting with simulating a double jointed arm in python, and I’ve finally got it working to the point where I think it might be worth sharing. I initially wrote the simulator from scratch but ran into instability issues, so I rewrote it using the frccontrol framework by @calcmogul. The instability issue returned there was well, but at least now the code is a little cleaner.

My code can be found in this fork of frccontrol in examples/double_jointed_arm.py. I was initially hoping to easily merge this back into the main frccontrol repository, but I needed to make more changes to the framework than expected so that might come at a later date.

The arm simulated in code uses FRC 971 2018’s arm parameters from their github, which I heavily based my original simulator on.

The first portion of this program is the simulator. It is based on the two jointed arm dynamics derived in my previous whitepaper, and implemented using Runge-Kutta Dormand Prince integration, since the standard RK4 method led to numerical instabilities with 971’s robot arm at a 20ms time step. Interestingly, making the arm heavier made the simulator more stable - there seems to be some critical (acceleration x time step) threshold where the simulator becomes unstable. With that said, the simulator can just be run at a 5ms or 1ms step and still run pretty fast.

The more interesting portion of the program is the controller. I will preface this by saying that I do not recommend any team implement this style of controller for the first time in-season, but maybe this simulator will be able to nudge this style of controller from a 971-exclusive to something that more teams are capable of using.

The basic summary is that the simulator uses an Extended Kalman Filter to estimate the state of the arm using how it thinks the arm should move (using the dynamics equations) and also using its sensor readings. This filter smooths sensor noise, which is generally not a problem for this specific application, but hypothetically could be an issue. More importantly, this filter allows us to perform something described in the FRC Controls textbook as “input error estimation,” where the controller looks at your system’s behavior, sees how it deviates from the expected, and estimates what changes it should make to the output to make the system behave going forward. This serves a similar purpose to an I term in a PID controller, but is more optimized to avoid the sluggish/delayed response characteristic to an integrator term.

This input error estimation should allow for robust arm control even as some unmodeled disturbances arise, e.g. the loads change (picking up a game piece), things get damaged, mechanical resistances change, etc.

The controller also implements LQR to solve the optimal proportional-error gains for controlling the arm. This part may be something that could be more realistic for teams to implement in their trajectory followers this year, but it would require a characterized double jointed arm. As far as I know, there is no standard routine established for this sort of characterization.

Some simulator animations are below. The dashed blue line represents the target trajectory, the red line represents where the arm is simulated to actually be, and the dashed green line represents where the controller’s Kalman filter estimates the arm is.

No disturbances:

Constant unmodeled torque of 150 Nm on the first joint and -90 Nm on the second joint (these are very large loads. For reference, 1/2" hex fails at 250 Nm):

Note how the input error estimates settle to 150 and -90, matching the actual unmodeled errors that we introduced.

Doubled gravity strength:

Note that these disturbances are very extreme, and the controller doesn’t know about them ahead of time - it manages to compensate for them pretty impressively on the fly in just a few seconds.

Please let me know if you have any questions - I learned a lot from putting this together, and hopefully someone else can learn a thing or two from it as well.

rafi:

it would require a characterized double jointed arm. As far as I know, there is no standard routine established for this sort of characterization.

Since you’re using input error estimation, plugging in the motor constants from a DCMotor instance and link masses and lengths will probably be close enough. If not, there’s ways to do system ID on nonlinear models:
https://underactuated.mit.edu/sysid.html#example5
